title: What is the difference between a golden clarinet and a soprano saxophone? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s also an actual golden clarinet in Sponge Bob Squarepants https://spongebob.fandom.com/wiki/Golden_clarinet, If indeed this is used as slang for a soprano sax, as apparently it is, it evinces a fundamental confusion since saxes and clarinets of any size/pitch are very different instruments - saxes have a conical (tapered) bore and clarinets are cylindrical (even bore for the main part of the body), this means that saxes overblow at the first harmonic, the octave, and clarinets at the second, octave and a fifth, giving clarinets a larger range but with a weak middle. But unless you play, you wouldn’t know or care.

Apparently “golden clarinet” is urban slang for a soprano sax, so there is no difference. The term may have evolved because the majority of people expect a sax to be curved in a certain way. However the most common form of soprano sax is straight like a clarinet. There are also curved versions - I have several of both types.
